channel.title: Great Himalaya Trail on Wilderness Prime
channel.description: Recent content in Great Himalaya Trail on Wilderness Prime

item.title: Frequently Asked Questions
item.description: Safety First a quick note about safety. The Great Himalaya Trail is a dangerous undertaking, with sections where one trip or wrong footstep can be fatal. Towards the end of our thru-hike we got in touch with a girl named Milena Piasecka from Poland. We gave her advice on various subjects as she planned here GHT, and she started just as we were finishing. A couple of months later, in the Everest region, she was tragically killed in a fall.

item.title: Trail notes
item.description: .print-only { display: none; } @media print { #header, #nav, #breadcrumbs, header.major, #author, #next-section, #prev-section, #footer, #copyright, #navPanel { display:none!important; } body, #wrapper, #main, section.post, div.content { margin:0!important; padding:0!important; width:100%!important; } * { font-size: 100%!important; line-height: 130%!important; } p, td { font-size: 1rem!important; } h2 { font-size: 1.5rem!important; } h4 { font-size: 1rem!important; } table td { padding: 0.25rem 0.25rem } h1, h2 { margin: 2rem 0 1rem 0; } h3, h4 { margin: 0 0 1rem 0; } p { margin: 0 0 1rem 0; } .

item.title: Reddit AMA
item.description: I'll be hosting a Reddit AMA about the trek today under my username davebrophy. I hiked the Great Himalaya Trail for 154 days across the highest trails of Nepal. Ask me anything! from r/IAmA

item.title: The Great Himalaya Trail vlog
item.description: In the summer of 2019 we spent five months hiking the Great Himalaya Trail across Nepal. Every day I made a vlog video of the trek. I've finally got them ready to show the world. Here's the trailer - the vlog episodes start on February 1st. Feel free to subscribe / share. This has been a huge project over the past few months and I'm super happy with the result!

item.title: Day 120 - Utterly spectacular scenery as we enter Dolpa
item.description: Today we hiked from Kagbeni (2,810 m) to Santa (3,780 m).

item.title: Day 118 - A spectacular trail down the valley
item.description: Today we hiked from Namu Kharka (4,180 m) to Kagbeni (2,810 m).

item.title: Day 117 - Two high passes in one day
item.description: Today we hiked from Tilicho Lake Viewpoint (5,000 m) to Namu Kharka (4,180 m) via Tilicho East (5,340 m) and Mesokanto La (5,250 m).

item.title: Day 116 - A lovely hike until the weather turned
item.description: Today we hiked from Tilicho Lake Base Camp (4,140 m) to Tilicho Lake Viewpoint (5,000 m).

item.title: Weekly summary #13
item.description: This is a weekly summary of the trek from day 108 to 115. Day 108 Today we hiked from Samdo (3,870 m) to Bimtang (3,590 m) via Larkya La (5,160 m). Day 109 Today we hiked from Bimtang (3,590 m) to Tilche (2,280 m). Day 110 Today we hiked from Tilche (2,280 m) to Timang (2,600 m). Day 111 Today we hiked from Timang (2,600 m) to Bratang (2,910 m).

item.title: Day 115 - Big changes to our plans
item.description: Today we hiked from Manang (3,540 m) to Tilicho Lake Base Camp (4,140 m).

item.title: Day 113 - Staying in a cute little rabbit hutch
item.description: Today we hiked from Upper Pisang (3,280 m) to Manang (3,540 m).

item.title: Day 112 - A beautiful monestary and stunning scenery
item.description: Today we hiked from Bratang (2,910 m) to Upper Pisang (3,280 m).

item.title: Day 111 - An amazing deluxe guesthouse
item.description: Today we hiked from Timang (2,600 m) to Bratang (2,910 m).

item.title: Day 110 - We made a friend today
item.description: Today we hiked from Tilche (2,280 m) to Timang (2,600 m).

item.title: Day 109 - A nice easy day to join the Annapurna Circuit
item.description: Today we hiked from Bimtang (3,590 m) to Tilche (2,280 m).

item.title: Day 108 - Crazy long day over the pass
item.description: Today we hiked from Samdo (3,870 m) to Bimtang (3,590 m) via Larkya La (5,160 m).

item.title: Weekly summary #12
item.description: This is a weekly summary of the trek from day 99 to 107. Day 99 Sick day Day 100 Today we hiked from Kashigaun (1,890 m) to Khorlabesi (870 m). Day 101 Today we hiked from Khorlabesi (870 m) to Jagat (1,340 m). Day 102 Rest day Day 103 Day 104 Today we hiked from Jagat (1,340 m) to Deng (1,860 m). Day 105 Today we hiked from Deng (1,860 m) to Namrung (2,630 m).

item.title: Day 107 - A nice easy hike instead of a rest day
item.description: Today we hiked from Sama (3,520 m) to Samdo (3,870 m).

item.title: Day 106 - Another lovely day but lower visibility
item.description: Today we hiked from Namrung (2,630 m) to Sama (3,520 m).

item.title: Day 105 - Most beautiful day of the entire trek?
item.description: Today we hiked from Deng (1,860 m) to Namrung (2,630 m).

item.title: Day 104 - Easier than we expected
item.description: Today we hiked from Jagat (1,340 m) to Deng (1,860 m).

item.title: Day 101 - More pleasant trekking but we're suffering in this humidity
item.description: Today we hiked from Khorlabesi (870 m) to Jagat (1,340 m).

item.title: Day 100 - First enjoyable day in weeks
item.description: Today we hiked from Kashigaun (1,890 m) to Khorlabesi (870 m).

item.title: Weekly summary #11
item.description: This is a weekly summary of the trek from day 89 to 98. Day 89 Today we hiked from Gatlang (2,230 m) to Somdang (3,260 m). Day 90 Today we hiked from Somdang (3,260 m) to Tipling (1,890 m). Day 91 Today we hiked from Tipling (1,890 m) to Borang (1,540 m). Day 92 Today we hiked from Borang (1,540 m) to Lapagaon (1,290 m). Day 93 Rest day

item.title: Day 98 - An easy day but Mathi is getting sick again

item.title: Day 95 - Mathi got sick now I'm feeling sick. Bad times
item.description: Today we hiked from Lapagaon (1,290 m) to Myangal Kharka (2,910 m).

item.title: Day 92 - Hopes of a deluxe hotel are sadly unfounded

item.description: Today we hiked from Gatlang (2,230 m) to Somdang (3,260 m).

item.title: Weekly summary #10
item.description: This is a weekly summary of the trek from day 77 to 88. Day 77 Today we hiked from Tin Pokhari (4,250 m) to High Camp South (4,980 m). Day 78 Today we hiked from High Camp South (4,980 m) to Kharka (4,540 m) via Tilman's Pass (5,310 m). Day 79 Today we hiked from Kharka (4,540 m) to Langshisa Kharka (4,120 m). Day 80 Today we hiked from Langshisa Kharka (4,120 m) to Kyangjin Gompa (3,880 m).

Day 64 Today we hiked from Laduk (2,050 m) to Loting (1,770 m). Day 65 Today we hiked from Loting (1,770 m) to Bigu Gompa (2,520 m).

Day 46 Today we hiked from Dzongla (4,830 m) to Gokyo (4,790 m) via Cho La (5,420 m). Day 47 Day 48 Today we hiked from Gokyo (4,790 m) to Cho Oyu Base Camp (5,160 m). Day 49 Today we hiked from Cho Oyu Base Camp (5,160 m) to Gokyo (4,790 m).

item.title: Weekly summary #5
item.description: This is a weekly summary of the trek from day 37 to 43. Day 37 Today we hiked from Makalu Base Camp (4,870 m) to Swiss Base Camp (5,150 m). Day 38 Today we hiked from Swiss Base Camp (5,150 m) to Sherpani Col High Camp (5,690 m). Day 39 Today we hiked from Sherpani Col High Camp (5,690 m) to Barnutse Base Camp (5,440 m) via Sherpani Col (6,190 m) and West Col (6,140 m).

item.description: Today we hiked from Amphu Labsta Base Camp (5,530 m) to Chhukung (4,730 m) via Amphu Labsta (5,850 m).

item.title: Day 41 - Insane scenery as we approach the pass
item.description: Today we hiked from Hunku Khola Camp (5,070 m) to Amphu Labsta Base Camp (5,530 m).

item.title: Day 40 - Diversion - Mathi is getting sick
item.description: Today we hiked from Barnutse Base Camp (5,440 m) to Hunku Khola Camp (5,070 m).

item.title: Day 39 - The highest point of the trek
item.description: Today we hiked from Sherpani Col High Camp (5,690 m) to Barnutse Base Camp (5,440 m) via Sherpani Col (6,190 m) and West Col (6,140 m).

item.title: Day 38 - Most difficult terrain yet
item.description: Today we hiked from Swiss Base Camp (5,150 m) to Sherpani Col High Camp (5,690 m).

item.title: Day 37 - Our first good look at Everest
item.description: Today we hiked from Makalu Base Camp (4,870 m) to Swiss Base Camp (5,150 m).

item.description: This is a weekly summary of the trek from day 29 to 36. Day 29 Day 30 Today I flew from Khola Kharka (3,210 m) to Khongma Danda (3,620 m). Day 31 Today we hiked from Khongma Danda (3,620 m) to Dobate (3,850 m). Day 32 Today we hiked from Dobate (3,850 m) to Yangla Kharka (3,760 m). Day 33 Today we hiked from Yangla Kharka (3,760 m) to Langmale Kharka (4,410 m).

item.title: Day 36 - An easy acclimatisation hike
item.description: Today we hiked from Makalu Base Camp (4,870 m) to Swiss Base Camp (5,150 m) and back.

item.description: Today we hiked from Langmale Kharka (4,410 m) to Makalu Base Camp (4,870 m).

item.description: This is a weekly summary of the trek from day 19 to 28. Day 19 Rest day Day 20 Waiting for the weather Day 21 Today I hiked from Olangchun Gola (3,430 m) to Pass Camp (4,450 m). Day 22 Today I hiked from Pass Camp (4,450 m) to Thudam (3,560 m) via Lumbha Sambha (5,160 m). Day 23 Today I hiked from Thudam (3,560 m) to Jijibuk (2,700 m).

item.description: Today I hiked from Lingham (2,220 m) to Hongon (2,320 m).

item.description: Today I hiked from Jijibuk (2,700 m) to Lingham (2,220 m).

item.description: Today I hiked from Thudam (3,560 m) to Jijibuk (2,700 m).

item.description: Today I hiked from Pass Camp (4,450 m) to Thudam (3,560 m) via Lumbha Sambha (5,160 m).

item.title: Day 21 - Incredibly hard hiking in waist deep snow
item.description: Today I hiked from Olangchun Gola (3,430 m) to Pass Camp (4,450 m).

item.title: Weekly summary #2
item.description: This is a weekly summary of the trek from day 9 to 18. Day 9 Acclimatisation day Day 10 Today I hiked from Khangpachen (4,050 m) to Lhonak (4,780 m). Day 11 Acclimatisation day Day 12 Today I hiked from Lhonak (4,780 m) to Kanchenjunga Base Camp (5,140 m). Day 13 Today I hiked from Kanchenjunga Base Camp (5,140 m) to Khangpachen (4,050 m). Day 14 Today I hiked from Khangpachen (4,050 m) to Ghunsa (3,600 m).

item.title: Day 18 - First really sketchy bridge of the trek
item.description: Today I hiked from Langjong Kharka (3,730 m) to Olangchun Gola (3,430 m).

item.title: Day 17 - Hard pass, cold feet. Found a great cabin
item.description: Today I hiked from Kharka (4,160 m) to Langjong Kharka (3,730 m).

item.title: Day 16 - Climbing up to the first pass
item.description: Today I hiked from Ghunsa (3,600 m) to Kharka (4,160 m).

item.title: Day 14 - The last of the easy bits
item.description: Today I hiked from Khangpachen (4,050 m) to Ghunsa (3,600 m).

item.title: Day 13 - Two days of hiking in one
item.description: Today I hiked from Kanchenjunga Base Camp (5,140 m) to Khangpachen (4,050 m).

item.title: Day 12 - Reached the base camp!
item.description: Today I hiked from Lhonak (4,780 m) to Kanchenjunga Base Camp (5,140 m).

item.title: Day 10 - Took a wrong turn into a terrifying landslide area
item.description: Today I hiked from Khangpachen (4,050 m) to Lhonak (4,780 m).

item.title: Weekly summary #1
item.description: This is a weekly summary of the trek from day 1 to 8. Day 1 Today I hiked from Taplejung (2,410 m) to Phurumbu (1,680 m). Day 2 Today I hiked from Phurumbu (1,680 m) to Chiruwa (1,270 m). Day 3 Today I hiked from Chiruwa (1,270 m) to Sukethum (1,580 m). Day 4 Today I hiked from Sukethum (1,580 m) to Amiljosa (2,310 m). Day 5 Today I hiked from Amiljosa (2,310 m) to Gyabla (2,730 m).

item.title: Day 8 - First day hiking solo
item.description: Today I hiked from Ghunsa (3,600 m) to Khangpachen (4,050 m).

item.title: Day 7 - The trail gets more rugged
item.description: Today I hiked from Gyabla (2,730 m) to Ghunsa (3,600 m).

item.title: Day 5 - Starting to feel the altitude, and getting sick?
item.description: Today I hiked from Amiljosa (2,310 m) to Gyabla (2,730 m).

item.title: Day 4 - What a slog
item.description: Today I hiked from Sukethum (1,580 m) to Amiljosa (2,310 m).

item.title: Day 3 - Cardamom forests
item.description: Today I hiked from Chiruwa (1,270 m) to Sukethum (1,580 m).

item.title: Day 2 - Bruises on my hips from my pack
item.description: Today I hiked from Phurumbu (1,680 m) to Chiruwa (1,270 m).

item.title: Day 1 - The first day!
item.description: Today I hiked from Taplejung (2,410 m) to Phurumbu (1,680 m).

item.title: Models
item.description: Post trail update This page is out of date. We didn't use the 3D models on the trek. Maps3d.io is an amazing service that easily converts a GPX route into a GLTF format 3D model, using satellite imagery and elevation data. These can be displayed on the web (as below) or in a mobile app. I've downloaded models for all 115 days to my phone, so while we're on the trek we should be able to preview the next section in glorious 3D.

item.title: Tilman's Pass
item.description: Post trail update See the Trail Notes page or this Google sheet for an updated description of this leg. 5,308m, D061 - Navigation on the approach to Tilman's is reportedly rather difficult. It's less technical than the other passes and lower elevation at just 5,308m. A steep scramble beside an icefall is followed by an crevassed plateau, then a steep scramble down. The exit is a long walk along a glacier with a tricky river crossing at the end.

item.title: Tashi Labsta La
item.description: Post trail update See the Trail Notes page or this Google sheet for an updated description of this leg. 5,760m, D043 - The route over Tashi Labsta La is a rocky scramble with constant danger from rockfall and crevasses. We'll have to be very careful on this section, but it's perhaps less technical than the previous three passes.

item.title: Amphu Labsta La
item.description: Post trail update See the Trail Notes page or this Google sheet for an updated description of this leg. 5,845m, D031 - Amphu Labsta La is reportedly one of the most dangerous passes in Nepal, and certainly the most technical point on our trek. Climbing a steep icefall will require full climbing safety gear, and the descent is just as tricky with a 30m rappel.

item.title: West Col
item.description: Post trail update See the Trail Notes page or this Google sheet for an updated description of this leg. 6,190m, D029 - The top of West Col is the highest point on the trek at 6,190m, but doesn't involve much climbing from the plateau. However a 200m rappel awaits on the other side. I've read disconcerting reports about the state of the fixed ropes on this section, so extreme care will have to be taken.

item.title: Sherpani Col
item.description: Post trail update See the Trail Notes page or this Google sheet for an updated description of this leg. 6,180m, D028 - Sherpani & West Col are two impressive passes connected by a glaciated plateau. The ascent of Sherpani is a tough scramble followed by some easy rock climbing, followed by a 35m rappel down to the plateau. Rockfall from above and crevasses will be a constant danger.

item.title: Mountaineering
item.description: Post trail update You can read more about the mountaineering sections on the Trail Notes page. Also check out the FAQ: What are the most difficult / technical parts?. The route has five passes that require moderate mountaineering skills and equipment. You can read more about the gear we'll be using on these sections on the Gear - Mountaineering page. We'll be enlisting the services of a mountaineering guide to assist us over these five sections - Sherpani Col, West Col, Amphu Labsta La, Tashi Labsta La and Tilman's Pass.

item.title: Trash
item.description: Post trail update We managed to ship all out trash back to Kathmandu, however the cost of shipping it out of the country was prohibitively expensive so we disposed of it in Kathmandu. As our backpacking food arrived I've been getting more and more concerned about the amount of plastic trash we'll be generating. The remote regions of Nepal have very limited rubbish disposal facilities, and plastic trash is often dumped.

item.title: Communication
item.description: Post trail update My InReach Mini worked flawlessly throughout the trek and should be considered absolutely essential. We'll be using a Garmin InReach Mini for communicating with the outside world during the trek. It uses the Iridium satellite network to allow two-way short message communication anywhere in the world, even when far away from a mobile network. It has several useful features: Messaging The device can send and receive short, 140 character messages.

item.title: Temperatures
item.description: Post trail update These temperatures worked pretty well as a very rough estimate. See the FAQ: What's the temperature like?. It's possible to work out the approximate temperatures on the trail by taking the average monthly temperatures in Kathmandu at 1,400m, and using the adiabatic lapse rate of 9.8C per km. This gives us a very approximate estimate of the temperature we'll be experiencing on the trail. The results show we'll be expecting a rather chilly -20C on some nights, but daytime temperatures rarely dip below freezing.

item.title: Sponsors - RxBars
item.description: Thanks very much to RxBar for sending us a selection of their RxBar energy bars. They'll make a great calorie dense breakfast, and made from real food ingredients.

item.title: Sponsors - Expedition Foods
item.description: Thanks very much to Expeditions Foods for offering us a generous discount on their 1,000 calorie Extreme Energy dehydrated meals. They're high calorie, energy dense meals perfect for a big expedition like this.

item.title: Sponsors - FBOMB
item.description: Thanks very much to FBOMB for sending us some of their Premium Oils and Nut Butter sachets. We'll be adding oil to our evening meals to give us a calorie boost, and the nut butter will make a great snack during the day.

item.title: Gear - Clothes
item.description: Post trail update Our clothes worked pretty well throughout the trek. Clothes I'll take a single change of underwear and long-sleeve t-shirt - both Icebreaker merino wool. I'll take a pair of Darn Tough socks for the warmer sections and a warmer pair of Smartwool socks for the cold sections. The boots I'll be using aren't particularly warm so I'll need the extra insulation. When it gets cold I'll be slipping into my Patagonia Capilene Air thermal layer, which is incredibly light for the warmth it provides.

item.title: Gear - Miscellaneous
item.description: Post trail update We had major problems with solar panels. The Suntactics S5-Lite was underpowered and almost completely useless. We switched to using the 21W panels at one of the early resupply points, however these also caused problems. See the FAQ: Power. Many of the water sources along the trek are silty and would clog a filter, so we switched to using chlorine tablets at the first resupply point and continued like this for the rest of the trek.

item.title: Gear - Mountaineering
item.description: Post trail update I hugely regret not taking my crampons and ice axe on the first section (from Kanchenjunga Base Camp to Makalu Base Camp). The first few high sections (Nango La, Lumbha Sumbha, Molun Pokhari) were all extremely dangerous without crampons. Our mountaineering gear all worked extremely well, however I think we were lucky that our Petzl Leopard crampons lasted the whole trek. The Dyneema cord joining the front and back of the crampons together was badly worn from walking across rocks, and could have snapped at any time.

item.title: Gear - Cooking
item.description: Post trail update Our cooking system worked pretty well. One problem was that the Kovea Spider stove was tricky to keep alight with even the slightest wind, so I would probably swap for a more windproof stove if I was to do the trek again. It never got cold enough that we had to invert the canister. I've chosen to take a canister stove - we'll be getting regular resupply packages that will replenish our gas supplies, so a heavy complex liquid fuel stove won't be needed.

item.title: Gear - Sleeping
item.description: Post trail update Our sleep system worked extremely well. We used the Feathered Friends Snowbunting sleeping bags for the first sections, and as the temperature increased we swapped to the much lighter Zpacks bags. We didn't get much use out of the Evazote foam pads, so sent these hope at the first resupply point. I had initially intended to use my Zpacks 20F (-7C) sleeping bags, augmented with down jacket and pants.

item.title: Gear - Camping
item.description: Post trail update We had a problem with the zip of our tent, but overall it performed well. The downside of a large tent like this is that it needs a lot of space to set up. There were several campsites where we needed to take extra time to scout out a sufficiently large spot to erect it. We'll be sleeping in a Hyperlite Mountain Gear Ultamid 4, which is a extremely sturdy four-season pyramid tent made of ultra light DCF fabric.

item.title: Gear - Pack
item.description: Post trail update The Arc Blast is a great pack, but never designed for more than about 10kg. We were regularly carrying loads of 20kg, and the hip belt was extremely uncomfortable. I had bruises on my hips for several months after the end of the trek. I'll be using the ZPacks Arc Blast. This is my third Arc Blast and without a doubt my favourite ever pack. The feather light 605g combined with the amazing load isolation is an unbeatable combination.

item.title: Interactive Map
item.description: Post trail update This page is out of date. See the Trail Notes page for the updated itinerary. Here's an interactive map of the route. You can use the tabs at the bottom to zoom in to the detail of a single day.

item.title: Food
item.description: Post trail update With hindsight I would have taken less camping food. See the Itinerary - Resupply page for more information. We will eat as much freshly prepared food as we can. Dal Bhat is delicious and we want to support the local economy as much as possible. However, we'll only have access to locally prepared food on about half the 115 days in the itinerary. The rest of the food we'll have to take with us.

item.title: Navigation - Apps
item.description: Post trail update This page is out of date. For my latest recommendation on navigation apps, see the FAQ: What navigational sources would you recommend?. Unfortunately I've not yet found an app that has all the features I need for navigating a long trek like the Great Himalaya Trail, so I'll be using these three apps in combination: ViewRanger Advantages: Great maps. Ultimate flexibility - you can load lots of routes and adjust colours etc.

item.title: Navigation - Emergencies
item.description: Post trail update This page is out of date. Unfortunately due to a couple of problems, using my Garmin Fenix watch as an emergency navigation aid wasn't ideal: There's a frustrating limitation of 1000 waypoints on the Garmin Fenix 5 watch. I can't find any way around is, so I had to reduce the km markers to one every 3km. This made the system less useful. I kept the watch in an accessible pocket on the outside of my pack, however this meant that the watch would accidentally get turned on, which ran the battery out.

item.title: Navigation - Flashcards
item.description: Post trail update This page is out of date. After the trek I created a comprehensive set of trail notes that can be downloaded as a PDF for printing. I would recommend using these instead of the flashcards detailed below, which were often rather out of date. See the Trail Notes page. Robin's guide book is excellent, but not organised optimally for a thru-hike of the GHT. I created a set of flashcards, one for each day of our itinerary.

item.title: Navigation - GPS routes
item.description: Post trail update This page is out of date. After the trek I updated and improved my GPX route files, and I would recommend using the latest version as your primary navigation route. You can download the GPX files on the Trail Notes page. Also see the FAQ: What navigational sources would you recommend?. ViewRanger will provide topo maps of the entire trekking area, but these would be of limited use without the route highlighted.

item.title: Navigation - Methods
item.description: Post trail update This page is out of date. For my latest recommendation on navigation methods, see the FAQ: What navigational sources would you recommend?. Navigating with the aid of digital topo maps is a game changer for unsupported trekking. However, extreme care must be taken because digital devices often fail in the field. We will be using several backups to mitigate this: My iPhone with topo mapping, offline maps and GPX route (see Navigation - Apps article).

item.title: Itinerary - Resupply
item.description: Post trail update This page is out of date. Prior to the trek we had no idea where we would be able to resupply with food that could be prepared with a backpacking stove, so we assumed we would never resupply along the trek. This meant we were carrying far too much food for much of the trek. See the FAQ: When can you resupply with camping food along the route.

item.title: Itinerary - Summary
item.description: Post trail update This page is out of date. See the Trail Notes page or this Google sheet for the updated itinerary. In any trek it's important to get an idea of the approximate itinerary. Of course, on a long trek like this the exact route will need to be flexible, but I'll plan the intended route and the maps and guide book will provide alternates when we need them.

item.title: Navigation - Sources
item.description: Post trail update This page is out of date. For my latest recommendation on navigation sources, see the FAQ: What navigational sources would you recommend?. Navigation is critical for any expedition, and especially those venturing into remote areas where the trail network is more tenuous. You'll realise I'm a great believer in technology - however I'd like to point out from the outset that a paper map backup is always required.

item.title: What is the Great Himalaya Trail?
item.description: The Great Himalaya Trail is the combination of several trail networks stretching the length of the Himalaya range, with sections in India, Nepal, Bhutan and Tibet. Our trek will follow the High Route of the Nepal section from Kanchenjunga on the Indian border in the East to Hilsa on the Chinese border in the West. The concept of the high route is that it follows the highest feasible continuous route across the country, averaging 3,750m (12,000ft) of elevation, with several passes taking us over 6,100m (20,000ft).
